Choose backend stack

Pick a stack and API style. We will keep everything local and safe.

API style

We will assume REST for the templates but remember to validate either way.

Endpoint template viewer

Generate a tiny endpoint with validation/auth placeholders for the chosen stack.

// GET /health
router.get("/health", async (req, res) => {
  // TODO: input validation (query/body)
  return res.status(200).json({ status: "ok", ts: Date.now() });
});

API design checklist

Tick the boring-but-important boxes. Your future self will send you a thank you note.

API health0/100

This is basically a haunted house.

API design lab

This is about contracts. Clients depend on shape, errors, and stability more than they depend on your favourite framework.

Request body
Response body

Guidance

  • Use nouns for resources and HTTP methods for intent (GET fetches, POST creates, PATCH updates).
  • Make errors predictable and safe. Clients should know what to do next.
  • Version when you must break clients. Prefer additive changes when possible.
  • Document auth requirements per endpoint, not only globally.

Failure and abuse thinking

Tie your API decisions directly to security and reliability outcomes.

Authn vs authz: authentication proves who the user is; authorisation decides what they can do.

Validation: treat every input as hostile until proven otherwise. Reject early with clear messages.

Rate limiting: protect availability and cost. A 429 should include guidance for retry behaviour.

Idempotency: POST endpoints that can be retried should have an idempotency key to avoid double charging.

Your current draft

GET /api/orders (URI versioning (/v1)). Errors: 400/401/403/404/409/429/500. Resource: orders.
